premise: Opioid and stimulant use has seen a significant rise in the US.

Mandy Owens, PhD, a clinical psychologist and researcher at the University of Washington Alcohol and Drug Abuse Institute, says she’s observed a spike in substance use in the US that includes an increase in both quantity and frequency of drug use during the pandemic.
As their stress increases, people in the US may have fewer ways to manage it, which Owens says probably contributes to the uptick in substance use.
According to the National Survey on Drug Use and Health (NSDUH), 19.7 million American adults (aged 12 and older) battled a substance use in 2017, 2 million more than the year before.

While substance use is on rise in the US, environmental factors that may increase a person’s risk of addiction include a chaotic home environment and abuse, parent’s drug use and attitude toward drugs, peer influences, community attitudes toward drugs, and poor academic achievement.
Researchers have observed increases in substance use and drug overdoses in the United States since the COVID-19 pandemic was declared a national emergency in March 2020.
